{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3127192,"name":"Kevin Yang","username":"keviny","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/keviny/{size}/173086_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-16T02:37:05.171Z","cooked":"

Hello!

I’m from team 2877. We’re currently thinking of building a Pink Arm like mechanism to reach the high node. We were looking at previous designs of Pink Arms–specifically from Roboteers–and saw that they used a VersaPlanetary to achieve a 410:1 ratio with two 775s to drive their pivoting mechanism.

I wanted to get the community’s thoughts on whether it is a good idea to use VersaPlanetary on pivoting arms that extend 70+ inches with an end effector on its end (I estimate around ~20 pounds?). If you’ve tried this, what is your past experience? Are there problems that can arise from the small gears inside the Versa Planetary? Will they strip from having to rotate such a large load?

Roboteer 2018 CAD:

image1309×707 123 KB

image1162×826 137 KB

JVN Calculator using 20DP gears on top, and the Roboteer gearing table on the bottom:

image1122×773 77.4 KB

2023","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3127211,"name":"Jon Stratis","username":"Jon_Stratis","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jon_stratis/{size}/2663_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-16T03:17:23.398Z","cooked":"

I would consider using chain for the final reduction instead of gears. With chain, you have half the teeth on the sprocket supporting it. With gears, it’s just a couple of teeth - a much great chance of sheering the teeth on the gears and wrecking your whole day! Plus, chain can help absorb any impact loads, and lets you get the motors and gearboxes lower, which helps with center of gravity.

Do you have the CAD link/file for this?

Will it work? Yes, until it doesn’t…

I would use something else, but if you insist on VPs, stay away from the 7:1 and 10:1 stages. They are particularly weak.
